concept.title: About the Canon Wireless Flash System
concept.shortdesc: The Canon wireless flash system enables you to control multiple Speedlite flashes by using a pre-flash. The preflash sends information to all flashes such as sync mode and firing power.

conbody.p: Flashes in a wireless system consist of one master and many slaves. The master can be either a Speedlite or the ST-2 Wireless Flash Controller. Not all Speedlites can be configured to be a master. For example, the 580 EX II can be a master, but not the 430 EX II. Any Speedlite can be a slave, however.

You configure a Canon external flash to become a master flash by making settings on the flash itself or by adjusting flash settings in the camera. When an external flash is acting as a master, it can control any number of slave flashes. You configure an external flash to be a slave by adjusting settings on the flash.

Each slave flash can be assigned to a group. The Canon wireless system supports three groups: A, B, and C. You can control the flash power of each group separately by making settings on the master flash or in the camera.

section.title: Manual Flash
section.p: When Speedlites are set in manual mode, you can control the power level of each group separately from the camera or from the Speedlite control panel. Examples of power levels include 1/1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, and so on, all the way to 1/128.

section.title: E-TTL Flash
section.p: When flashes are set in E-TTL mode, you adjust the power levels of each group by setting power ratios. You can set the ratio of the group A level to the group B as 1:1, 1:2, 1:4 and so on, or as 1:1: 2:1, 4:1 and so on.

section.title: Examples
section.p: and describe some sample multiple-light setups.

example.title: Classic Two-Light Setup, Off-Camera Flash, E-TTL Mode
example.p: In the classic off-camera two-light setup, you use one flash as the key light, and one as the fill light. The key light is the master, attached to the camera with a long E-TTL cord, and is at camera-left at a 45 degree angle to the subject.
example.note: By default, the master is always in group A.
example.p: The fill light is at camera-right, also at a 45 degree angle and is in Group B. The ratio of group A to group B is set to 2:1, so that the key light is brighter than the fill light.

example.title: Three-Light Setup, Off-Camera Flash, Manual Mode
example.p: This setup uses a key and fill light, but also uses a rim light (or “hair light”) to separate the subject from the background. The rim light is placed behind and above the subject, and is in group C. All flashes are set to manual operation. The key light’s power is set to 1/2, the fill light to 1/4, and the rim light to 1/2. Because the ST-2 Wireless Flash Controller can control only two groups, you must use a Speedlite as the master.
